newsitem.title: TURKEY: Turk sell-off board to rule on halted Etibank sale.
newsitem.headline: Turk sell-off board to rule on halted Etibank sale.

text.p: Turkey's High Board of Privatisation is to rule on the delayed sale of Etibank after the agreed buyer failed to make the necessary downpayment, the Privatisation Administration Board (OIB) said in a statement.
Textile producer Dogan Kumascilik made a successful $185 million bid in March for Etibank, the second state bank to be privatised under a government sell-off programme.
But the company failed to meet a deadline, extended to June 23, to pay a deposit of 200 billion lira ($1.4 million), the administration board said.
It said it had transferred a previous 200 billion lira deposit to the privatisation fund.
According to the agreement signed in March, Dogan Kumascilik was to make a cash downpayment of $74 million and pay the remaining sum over two years.
Analysts said the OIB could decide to sell the bank to the second highest bidder, Diler Holding, which offered a price of $181 million.
They also said the tender could be cancelled and the bank might be offered for sale from scratch.
The government sold Sumerbank, the first bank to be sold off, for $103.5 million in 1995 to a textiles and brewery and company.
